{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3658427,"name":"Steve Seguin","username":"Stephen6875","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f1d935/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-20T00:16:34.269Z","cooked":"

Hi all, just recently got photonvision up and running on a jetson orin nano developer kit, and have a fisheye drive (arducam IMX291) and an Innomaker OV9281 for April tags. The driver can works flawlessly, and the OV9281 works fine until I go to perform calibration, then I instantly get the “camera lost” graphic.

If I cancel the calibration and restart it, the image briefly appears before disappearing again. I can only get the image back by unplugging the USB and plugging it in again.

In the photonvision logs, I get a couple errors, and one warning. Not sure if it’s the camera, or if I’m doing something wrong?

Had anyone had this type of issue with the Inno maker OV9281?

Looks like the stream is lost when Auto Exposure is enabled.

*Edited title and posts so that the actual manufacturer name is correct as innomaker, not innovision

This seems to be fairly common with this camera. This might serve as a solution for your issue, it would be great if you could leave a note with your hardware setup and whether the solution worked as well. Thanks!

This workaround was successful for me as well.
nVidia Jetson Orin Nano Super Development kit with Jetpack 6.2 installed on a 128GB SD card.
innomaker OV9281
Arducam IMX291 wide angle camera also connected

I do have another question though based on my novice experience with Linux:

Following all of the instructions results in the cloning of the git repository to the jetson, however now I want it to start on boot up (naturally, or we won’t be able to use it in competition). All the instructions to do so reference the jar file, which I haven’t downloaded.

Do I have to download the jar, run it and set everything up again, or is there another way for the jetson?

definitely not my area of expertice here…

But when you build photonvision locally how are you starting it? My understanding is you build the jar with gradle then run it?

Just curious what you’re doing different, I’m like 95% certain that’s the jar in reference here.

Just not sure how to get that to run as a service so it can be headless.

Using ./gradlew shadowJar will generate the jar.

PhotonVision Documentation

Build Instructions

This section contains the build instructions from the source code available at our GitHub page. Development Setup: Prerequisites: Java Development Kit: This project requires Java Development Kit (J...

As for starting is as a service seems pretty simple, but I don’t know enough about it to give an exact answer, some quick googling has promising looking results, I would assume its as simple as creating a script to run java -jar app.jar
